headline: Mitch McConnell Warns GOP Could Screw Up Senate Takeover in Midterm Election with "Unacceptable Candidates"
author: Madz Dizon
sentences: She was confirmed by a 53-47 vote, with three Republican senators - Mitt Romney of Utah, Susan Collins of Maine, and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska - voting for her, but her confirmation hearings in the Senate Judiciary Committee were tense, with questions about her sentencing in child porn cases, her views on critical race theory, and her judicial philosophy, as per New York Post.

Read Also: Kevin McCarthy Not Committed To Impeach President Biden Even If Republicans Recapture the House in 2022
Republicans Will Push Joe Biden to Center, Says McConnell
If Republicans take control of Congress in November, they will compel President Biden to forsake his progressive program and shift toward the center, according to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) stated Tuesday that the political climate is favorable for Republicans heading into the midterm elections, but he warned that the party's chances might be jeopardized if unpopular candidates win primaries then lose in November.

Along with possible clashes over the administration's policies, the question of whether a Republican-controlled Senate would undertake hearings for a second Biden Supreme Court nominee, following the heated hearings for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, might explode.

McConnell Warns GOP Not To Take Midterms for Granted
In a speech to a Kentucky chamber of commerce, McConnell claimed that 1994 was the finest year for Republicans and that the environment leading into November is better than it was in 1994.

McConnell then took a shot at Biden's administration, claiming that it "just can't seem to get their act together on the economy," which has resulted in low polling for Biden and increased the likelihood of Republicans winning majorities.

Republicans are bullish about their chances of retaking the Senate, but they must navigate numerous tumultuous primaries that might affect the general election map and the GOP's chances of gaining or maintaining a seat.
On Saturday night, Trump outraged Pennsylvania conservatives by endorsing TV personality Dr. Mehmet Oz, a more moderate Republican candidate for the state's open Senate seat.
Republicans are defending 21 seats, while Democrats are defending 14, including two seats now held by Republicans in states that President Biden won in 2020.

Three of them are now controlled by Democrats (Nevada, Georgia, and Arizona) while two are held by Republicans (Pennsylvania and Wisconsin).
As a result, Republican Rep. Vicky Hartzler, who is deemed more electable across the state, has surged to the head of the pack.
Republicans would only need a net gain of one member in the Senate to tilt the current 50-50 split in their favor in November.
If challenged by a Republican-controlled Congress, John Thune believes Biden will have to change his political stance.
He also confirmed that he and Democratic President Joe Biden, a former Senate colleague, still had a good connection.
During the interview, McConnell also affirmed that if the GOP wins in November, he will seek majority leader.
Because Vice President Kamala Harris, as Senate president, can break a tie, Democrats have a majority.
Former President Donald Trump has tried to play kingmaker in the 2022 elections again this week.
